data.title: Stanford Alumni Arts Grant – Stanford Arts
data.text:
Joel Chapman is a conductor, bass-baritone, and songwriter in the Bay Area. He sings professionally with Volti, an SF-based ensemble that performs and animates completely new works, as well as Endersnight, a choir specializing in Renaissance music. A sought-after low bass, Joel has been made appearances with groups peppered throughout the Bay Area, including the San Mateo Masterworks Chorale, Convivium, California Bach Society, and Stanford Chamber Chorale. Music directing credits: Tinderella (premiere, Custom Made Theatre Co) Voices of the Quilt (workshop, Custom Made), Sweeney Todd (SFBATCO), The Last Five Years, Sunday in the Park with George, My Fair Lady (Stanford University). As an educator, he teaches voice privately and works with the Piedmont Children’s Choir as a conductor and accompanist. Joel is a Stanford graduate and holds a B.A. in Music and M.A. in Music, Science, and Technology. | joelchapmanmusic.com

Weston Gaylord is a librettist, playwright, and mixed-reality creative technologist based in Los Angeles. He has worked to develop and produce narrative VR and AR experiences with Here Be Dragons, FX, The New York Times, Facebook, The United Nations, and the USC Shoah Foundation. His original work for the stage often combines live performance, music, and virtual and augmented reality: Chained: A Victorian Nightmare (Madison Wells Media, premiering 2018), Retrospective (Co.Reality), Lights Out Damn’d Spot (Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics), Ghost in the Machine (San Jose Rep Emerging Artists Lab, Stanford Institute of Design). Lyricist credits include Gravity: A New(tonian) Musical (TheatreWorks New Works Festival ’16) and Gaieties (Ram’s Head Theatrical Society). He holds a B.S. from Stanford University in Symbolic Systems with a focus in Human-Computer Interaction.

Matt Herrero is an actor, singer-songwriter, improviser, and playwright from the Bay Area. As an actor, Matt has shared the stage folks such as Michael Tilson Thomas (San Francisco Symphony) and David Hein and Irene Sankoff (Come From Away). He continues to work as a lead actor and co-author of the original musical, Gravity: A New(tonian) Musical (TheatreWorks, Z Space). His other recent theater credits include: Michael in The Bridges of Madison County (TheatreWorks Silicon Valley); Melchior in Spring Awakening (Stanford); Fedotik in Three Sisters (American Conservatory Theater). Matt has performed his original music up and down the West Coast, and has been featured in songwriting workshops led by Benjamin Scheuer (The Lion) and Casey Lee Hurt (The Unfortunates). Matt holds a B.S. from Stanford University (‘17) in Symbolic Systems with a focus in Computer Music. | mattherrero.com

Jessia Hoffman is a Bay Area-based improv coach, performer, educator, and freelance writer. She has taught, developed, and supported arts programming for TheatreWorks Silicon Valley, Signature Theatre (NYC), BATS Improv, Collective Capital, the Stanford Storytelling Project, Stanford Arts Intensive, and Stanford Improvisors. Select theatre credits: writer/director of SHEILA, an original play (Stanford Arts); co-creator of Gravity: A New(tonian) Musical (TheatreWorks Silicon Valley, Z Space); guest improviser for Un-Scripted Theatre Company; Carolyn in The Bridges of Madison County (TheatreWorks); Lisi in The Man in the Ceiling workshop (TheatreWorks); Tracy Turnblad in Hairspray (Stanford); Dot/Marie in Sunday in the Park with George (Stanford). Jessia aims to use theatre as a vehicle for social change and civic engagement, developing investigative new work. She holds a B.A. from Stanford University in English with a focus in Creative Writing, and Interdisciplinary Honors in the Arts.

Ken Savage is a San Francisco theater director and the Associate Producer at American Conservatory Theater where he produces for the mainstage, M.F.A. acting program, Young Conservatory, and other special projects in the Geary and Strand theaters. He also is the co-producer for A.C.T.'s annual New Strands Festival, in which he has ​​shepherded new works by Lucy Thurber/Casey Lee Hurt, Susan Soon He Stanton/Mina Morita, Dipika Guha/Jeremy Cohen, Christopher Chen/Byron Au Yong, Marisela Treviño Orta, Lucas Kavner, Lauren Yee, Don Nguyen, Dustin Chinn, and Darren Canady. Ken has worked with the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, the Public Theater, Arena Stage, CalShakes, TheatreWorks Silicon Valley, and Crowded Fire. He is a Stanford graduate (M.A. Communication with a focus on virtual reality and performance, B.A. Drama) and the recipient of the Silicon Valley Creates Artist Laureate Emerging Artist Award (2015). | kensavageproductions.com

Leanna Keyes is a playwright, producer, and designer based in the San Francisco Bay Area and Memphis, Tennessee. She works with a variety of Bay Area organizations devoted to the development of new and reimagined plays, including Playwrights Foundation, The Cutting Ball Theater, and Performance Design Acronym. She will be a playwright in residence at Crosstown Arts in Memphis from February to April 2019.

In 2018, her play Doctor Voynich and Her Children received collegiate productions at Rhodes College and at Stanford University, with more productions coming soon. Previously produced plays including God Herself Could Not Sink This Ship in 2014 and Legal-Tender Loving Care and The Kilogram Play in 2013. She also co-wrote the updated The Real World: Stanford with Olivia Haas, which was produced annually from 2015 to 2017.

Her plays have been studied at universities around the country, including Stanford University, Carnegie Mellon, Rhodes College, Linfield College, the University of Kansas, and Western Carolina University. In 2017, her work was featured at Carnegie Mellon in the curriculum of “American Women Playwrights of the 20th and 21st Centuries.”

Find out more at www.leannakeyes.com

Elijah Ndoumbé is a queer creative of the Black Diaspora who uses writing, film, and photography to challenge the dominant narrative around Black, Brown and Queer bodies as pathologized beings. Ndoumbé received their bachelors in African & African American Studies, and Feminist, Gender & Sexuality, at Stanford University. Ndoumbé has worked for organizations such as Warner Bros., artists such as Lena Waithe, and developed content for private clients, the Sex Workers’ Education and Advocacy Taskforce (SWEAT), Color of Change, IDA, as well as other independent organizations. They are currently based out of Woodstock where they work closely with SWEAT to produce visual content around the decriminalization of sex work, with an emphasis on supporting Queer and Trans communities of color.

Ndoumbé’s scattered Diasporic background – which saw them grappling with Blackness across geo-political boundaries early in life (born in France, moved to Los Angeles at the age of 9) – as well as their continued building of relationships with Black Queers around the world, allows them to be in conversation across Diaspora. The key with their work isn’t just in the content but also in the process, and the histories of what such processes have meant for many key populations captured and shared outside of their own context. Ndoumbe’s position as a Black, Trans, and gender- nonconforming individual – even within the complex racial-read of their current surroundings in South Africa – allows them access to communities that one doesn’t always get to see. Ndoumbé is focused on creating work asserting itself within the conversation around a decolonial aesthetic, and a radical archiving.

The push is to create artistic content which engages in the active processes of unlearning, re-shifting, and the questioning of hegemonic power structures – in the proximity of content to audiences, the process through which the work is captured, and also in its choice of materials and curation. Trust is a vital ingredient to their process.

What began with Undone (2015 – 2016) – an intimate portraiture series on Black and Queer individuals shot in London, New Orleans, and NYC – quickly saw Ndoumbé turning to visual art to portray and amplify the voices, spirits, and bodies of Black and Queer people. Undone came out of a need to see themselves – as well as a turning of the camera onto friends and chosen family, while finding the beauty so inherently present in their existence.

The Coffee Shop as Queer Salon, Parts I & II, and Portraits (2017-present) is a photographic and visual exploration that seeks to honor both a historical legacy and current moment of queer bodies within the context of the politics of space.

The project is also in conversation with how visual art can be a mechanism to establish agency for queer bodies. In this continued series, Ndoumbé focuses on the spatial dynamics and the occupation of queer bodies in the coffee shop space. The current archive of the series finds its roots in the Bay Area, California, USA.

In the spirit of embodied artistic work and collective re-imagining, Ndoumbé used an exhibit opening for Portraits from the Salon on display at the Field Office in February of 2018, in Woodstock, to collaborate with other local and queer artists of color to facilitate The Queer Salon. During the evening, members of Queer and Trans Communities of Color were invited in to share space, connect, create, and express themselves in community with one another.
